The mind of a human being is subject to many unaccountable fears, terrors, and anxieties. Infinite unknown evils are dreaded - sometimes from unknown agents/causes.

Thus ceremonies, rituals, observances, sacrifices, etc. are invented as the means of achieving peace of mind and physical safety in a world of real malevolence and imaginary threats.
 
 If this is brief summary of the primitive basis of religion is adequate, then it is difficult to avoid the conclusion that religion is a synonym for superstition.

Cancer is a loaded word, however its not hard to make links between the mimetic growth of religion and cancer.
 Essentially, religion doesn't need to really provide any benefit to the person in general yet can still spread because of conditions within society and in some cases (perfectly innocently) exploiting parts of the human brain that reduce the 'reality check' parts of the brain. Religion grows because conditions favour it, rather than because it is providing a discrete benefit (i.e not reality to its place in society).
